Apple 'Broke' Web Apps in iOS 17 Beta; Still Hasn't FixedÂ Them â€” Thereâ€™s been plenty of chatter about App Store changes, and PWAs in iOS 17 this week â€” all coming as a result of upcoming EU enforcement of the Digital Markets Act. This PWA bust is a change in the current beta, and the overall deadline for DMA compliance is in March â€”Â so things may change yet, but right now itâ€™s not looking great for all things PWA on iOS for those in theÂ EU.

Thomas Claburn

Hookdeck sponsor

CSS Mixins & Functions Explainer â€” Following a recent update from the CSS Working Group, Miriam captures the overall state of the conversation on developing CSS-native mixins and functions, including looking at how they would differ from existing pre-processors, and what extra functionality (or limitations) could come with such a browser level approach. A thorough, detailedÂ overview.

Miriam Suzanne

The Performance Inequality Gap in 2024 â€” Just how much HTML, CSS, and JavaScript can we afford to use in our projects? Alex digs in and notes that the answer is â€œmore than in years past, but much less than frontend developers are burdening usersÂ withâ€.

Alex Russell

Things Frequently Heard in My Beginning Frontend Web DevelopmentÂ Class â€” What could we learn from entry-level students in frontend web development? Geoff opines that it's newcomers to the space who ask the most intriguing questions and who make â€œconnections that those of us who have spent years on the front end may have neverÂ consideredâ€.

Geoff Graham

Tuple 'Makes Pair Programming with Co-Workers and Friends FunÂ Again' â€” Try Tuple for free and find out why staff engineers at Figma can't stop talking aboutÂ Tuple.

Tuple sponsor

Can Generative AI Help Write Accessible Code? â€” An experiment in asking three, free generative AI tools (Gemini, ChatGPT, and Fix My Code) some typical questions about accessibleÂ code.

LÃ©onie Watson

The New CSS Math: pow(), sqrt(), and Exponential Friends â€” These CSS functions are now available in the latest versions of Chrome, Edge, Firefox, and Safari. The pow() function mirrors the Math.pow() JavaScript functionality (for specifying how many times to multiply a number by itself). The sqrt() function is for finding the square root of a number. Dan shares details on these, where you might use them, and more. HandyÂ stuff.

Daniel Wilson

How I Solved My Font Rendering Problem â€” A quick fix for a variable font rendering issue onÂ iOS.

Michelle Barker

Nested Dark Mode via CSS Proximity â€” Jonathan notes that â€˜inheritanceâ€™ is probably the more accurate title here, but â€˜proximityâ€™ helped them define the conceptÂ better.

Jonathan Dallas

Brutalist Web Design â€” Guidelines for web design that adhere to the tenets and ethos of brutalism â€”Â a term more often associated with architecture. However, David notes that it can apply to other forms of construction, including webÂ design.

David Copeland

Andrey Sitnik

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Velvette: Making It Easier to Author CSS View Transitions â€” A small library that adds some features ostensibly missing from the View Transitions API (i.e. temporary classes during transition, unique name generation, andÂ others).

Noam Rosenthal

CheerpJ 3.0: A WebAssembly JVM to Run Real-World Apps in theÂ Browser â€” CheerpJ 3.0, a state-of-the-art WebAssembly JVM that runs real-world Java applications in the browser, is now available, although note that itâ€™s a commercial project (but free for personalÂ use).

Leaning Technologies

Open-Source Form Builder to Generate Dynamic JSON-Driven Forms Right in Your App â€” Integrate SurveyJS client-side form libraries in any JS app. Build forms in a no-code UI and maintain full control over the dataÂ flow.

SurveyJS sponsor

Tailwind CSS Button Collection: Click-to-Copy Animated Buttons â€” A gallery of more than 60 hover, click, and loading button effects built using Tailwind classes, some simple and others moreÂ unconventional.

Julien Thibeaut

ğŸ•°ï¸ ICYMI (Older links, still worth checking out)

  • This case study compares two identical site designs: one using Tailwind, another created with semantic CSS. The difference in markup isÂ remarkable.

  • Manuel MatuzoviÄ‡ shares an idea of how we can remove styling on a list without affecting semantics.

  • Here's how to load your site step-by-step, pausing the load to inspect things at each stage.

  • Chuck Grimmett ponders 'digital legacy', questioning how we can keep domains working long after we're gone.

ğŸ¤– ...and finally

CSS Neural Network (Number Detection) â€” This is kinda wild, and it feels like magic (but really it's just math!â„¢). You 'draw' in a number and the output updates with its best guess (â–¶ï¸ Quick video demo). It didnâ€™t work in Safari for me, but seems okÂ elsewhere. (The true 'magic' here is in the use of SCSS to create a lot of boilerplate â€“ well worth looking through, and then looking at the resulting CSS in DevTools.)

Bali Balo

Jen Simmons (WebKit)

Apple's Big Changes to iOS, Safari, and the App Store in the European Union â€” Sweeping changes are on the way for users of iOS, Safari, and the App Store in the EU, though developers worldwide will need to be aware of the changes too. Of particular note to frontend developers will be the introduction of alternative browser engines (i.e. non-WebKit poweredÂ browsers) starting with iOS 17.4. However, it isn't all going to be plain sailing...

Apple

Mozilla Says Appleâ€™s New Browser Rules are â€œAs Painful as Possibleâ€ for Firefox
Emma Roth (The Verge)

âœ¨ This is still a developing story, but Jason Grigsby has a roundup of what you need to know about the alternative browser engine support. Dave Rupert has also shared his initialÂ thoughts.

Auth Without Complexity â€” Auth In a Straightforward Platform â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Create signup and login forms, generate magic links, add SSO with Google, and more â€” all from a streamlined dashboard. Read the docsÂ now.

Userfront sponsor

Web Components in Earnest â€” A great walk through the journey behind building an app using Web Components and JavaScript â€”Â the author really shows off the realities of going all in with Web Components. The example app is simple, but complete all the same.

David Bryant Copeland

Highlight Text When a User Scrolls Down to That Piece of Text â€” Hereâ€™s how to create a neat animated text highlight effect that triggers based on a scroll-driven CSS class. No JavaScriptÂ required.

Chris Coyier

âš¡ï¸ Quick Links

  • ğŸ¤ª Anil Dash, writing for Rolling Stone, thinks the internet is ripe for change, and "about to get weird again". Bring it on.

CSS Blurry Shimmer Effect â€” Yair shares a step-by-step explanation of how this curious blurry shadow effect comes together, using a combo of masks, gradients, and the backdrop-filter property. CodePen demo.

Yair Even Or

Going Beyond Pixels and (r)ems in CSS - Relative Length Units Based on Font â€” Brecht invites us to take a little journey with him in to â€œthe wonderful world of <length> units inÂ CSS".

Brecht De Ruyte

Improving Enterprise Design Systems â€” Live stream for design system builders and users: How can we make working with design systems moreÂ seamless?

StackBlitz sponsor

A Configurable Switch using Modern CSS Techniques â€” Leaning on techniques such as :has(), container queries, logical properties and customÂ properties.

Andy Bell

â–¶Â Â Debugging Fetch Priority â€” A quick talk about the Large Contentful Paint metric, and how to improve it with the Fetch PriorityÂ API.

Chrome for Developers

â–¶Â Â The Evolution of Page Speed â€” A ~20-minute look at what Page Speed is, how we manage and optimize it, how it has changed over time, and what 2024 may have inÂ store.

Matt Zeunert (DebugBear)

The Coding Train â€” Eric Meyer recently put this on my radar â€” itâ€™s an ongoing, delightful beginner-friendly learning resource, covering things like WebGL, JavaScript, ML, APIs, and more. Plenty of challenges to take on, and great videos to follow along with. (Sidebar: how fun is the brandingÂ here?)

Daniel Shiffman

'Please, Donâ€™t Force Me to Log In' â€” â€œThe current accelerating trend of requiring accounts and logins for everything has toÂ stopâ€.

Juha-Matti Santala

The Web Accessibility Framework for Organizations â€” A resource explaining this new Web Accessibility Framework and how you can go about using it to help improve the approachability and availability of projects at an organizational level. Thereâ€™s a good related read here from Jay Pope explaining why it wasÂ created.

Whitney Lewis

Most Accessibility Issues Originate in Design (Plus How to Fix That)
Bogdan Cerovac

Nicer Text Wrapping with CSS text-wrap
Will Boyd

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

ğŸ…°Â Find and Try Variable Fonts â€” This site isnâ€™t new, but continues to be a handy resource for both finding and trying out a growing collection of variableÂ fonts, now supported by nearly all modern browsers. There's over 350 fonts on displayÂ now.

Nick Sherman

unlazy: A Universal Lazy Loading Library for Placeholder Images â€” It's framework-agnostic and intended to be used alongside loading="lazy" to provide temporary placeholder images as a pageÂ loads.

Johann Schopplich

Autosize Textarea: A Web Component for Auto-Resizing textarea Elements â€” This is one way to do this, but you could also opt for this pure CSS solution from a few yearsÂ back.

andrico karoulla

WebGPU-Kit â€” This is a minimal webGPU toolkit bringing together a collection of libraries that â€œmake it easy to build high-performance, cross-platform, web-based graphics applicationsâ€. GitHubÂ repo.

John Beresford

Palettify: An Interactive Playground to Customize and Preview UIÂ Themes â€” Currently supports MUI and shadcn-ui for the components and you can customize primary/secondary colors, accents, borders, cards, popovers, and others, before exporting as CSSÂ variables.

Mehdi Ben Hadj Ali

  • A look at how to approach reducing CSS size and improving performance on a big site, namely the UK Government's huge online presence.

  • Andrew Mosby shares an overview of the headless CMS landscape, opining on the most promising options.

  • Paul Scanlon shows us how to convert animations made using GSAP into animated GIFs.

  • Alex Podelko â€”Â a senior performance engineer at AWS â€” runs through the 'golden rule' of web performance and different performance engineeringÂ specializations.

ğŸ¿ ...and finally

ASCII Theater: Stream Text-Based Movies in Your Terminal â€” Putting copyright angles aside briefly, this is a neat experiment. Movies meet ASCII art in a bit of terminal fun. Want to give it a go? Grab the popcorn and run this at your terminal: ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=noÂ watch.ascii.theater .. then q to quit. (Note: We've had issues with it timing out, but the site and its aesthetic are worth experiencingÂ nonetheless.)
